title: 108_hr2278
content:
The Act is titled the "Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Corridor Act" and includes findings and purposes. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm transportation corridor in Alaska is a significant gateway with a rich history of indigenous people and pioneers. The region's natural beauty includes earthquake subsidence, avalanches, glaciers, and tidal action. The cultural landscape reflects human resilience in the face of rugged terrain and modern development. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm region in Alaska showcases human fortitude and resourcefulness in settling the frontier. It is geographically and culturally cohesive, defined by historic routes and a distinct landscape of mountains, lakes, and fjords. The region holds national significance with elements like the Iditarod National Historic Trail, the Seward Highway National Scenic Byway, and the Alaska Railroad National Scenic Railroad. The National Heritage Corridor designation in the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm region of Alaska supports the interpretation of historic routes and districts, promotes regional coordination and partnerships, and is backed by the Kenai Peninsula Historical Association and the Seward community. The Kenai Peninsula Historical Association, Seward Historical Commission, Seward City Council, Hope and Sunrise Historical Society, Hope Chamber of Commerce, Alaska Association for Historic Preservation, Cooper Landing Community Club, Alaska Wilderness Recreation and Tourism Association, Anchorage Historic Properties, Anchorage Convention and Visitors Bureau, Cook Inlet Historical Society, Moose Pass Sportsman's Club, Alaska Historical Commission, Girdwood Board of Supervisors, Kenai River Special Management Area Advisory Board, Bird/Indian Community Council, Kenai Peninsula Borough Trails Commission, Alaska Division of Parks and Recreation, Kenai Peninsula Borough, Kenai Peninsula Tourism Marketing Council, and Anchorage Municipal Assembly are all involved in the National Heritage Corridor designation in the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm region of Alaska. The purposes of this Act are to recognize, preserve, and interpret the historic and modern resource development and cultural landscapes of the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm historic transportation corridor, and to promote cooperative planning and partnerships among communities and government entities through financial and technical assistance. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. 
(1) Heritage corridor: Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Corridor.
(2) Management entity: 11 member Board of Directors of the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Corridor Communities Association.
(3) Management plan: plan for the Heritage Corridor.
(4) Secretary: Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 4. KENAI MOUNTAINS-TURNAGAIN ARM NATIONAL HERITAGE CORRIDOR. Establishment of the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Corridor and its boundaries are defined by a map. The management entity for the corridor is a Board of Directors. The Secretary will enter into a cooperative agreement with the management entity for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Corridor. The agreement will involve public participation and cover goals, conservation approach, and protection measures. The management entity is not authorized to take on management responsibilities on Federal lands. Representatives from various organizations will participate in developing and implementing the management plan for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Corridor, including the State Division of Parks and Outdoor Recreation, State Division of Mining, Land and Water, Forest Service, State Historic Preservation Office, Kenai Peninsula Borough, Municipality of Anchorage, Alaska Railroad, Alaska Department of Transportation, and National Park Service. SEC. 6. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF MANAGEMENT ENTITY. The management entity must develop a management plan for the Heritage Corridor within 3 years of entering into a cooperative agreement. The plan should include recommendations for conservation, funding, management, and development, as well as agreements with public and private organizations to protect the resources of the Corridor. Specific and potential funding sources should also be identified. The management entity must prioritize implementing actions, goals, and policies outlined in the cooperative agreement and management plan for the Heritage Corridor. This includes identifying funding sources, inventorying cultural and historic resources, and involving other Federal, State, and local agencies in the management of the Corridor. The management entity is responsible for carrying out programs that recognize resource values, encouraging economic viability, establishing interpretive exhibits, improving heritage trails, increasing public awareness, restoring historic buildings, and ensuring clear signage in the Heritage Corridor. The management entity in the Heritage Corridor conducts public meetings regarding the management plan, with notices in newspapers and meeting minutes available to the public. The Secretary may provide assistance as per the cooperative agreement for the purposes of the Act, subject to fund availability. Savings provisions are also outlined. SEC. 8. Savings provisions clarify that the management entity does not have zoning powers, does not affect government authority over land use, and does not restrict business activities. SEC. 9 prohibits the use of funds for acquiring real property. SEC. 10 authorizes appropriations for the Act's purposes. The Act authorizes $350,000 for the first year, with up to $1,000,000 for subsequent years. A maximum of $10,000,000 can be allocated for the Heritage Corridor. Federal funding must be matched by 25%. Grants or assistance cannot be provided beyond 15 years from the cooperative agreement.
